sn24.9:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.9:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.9:1.3.comm: Thus begins a series on the ten undeclared points (MN 25:10.21). This and the following views are “cosmology” (lokāyata), for which see SN 12.48.

sn24.9:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.9:2.1.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.9:2.1.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn24.9:2.5.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.9:2.5.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:

sn24.9:3.4.pli: vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:

sn24.9:3.12.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:

sn24.9:3.15.pli: “Yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?

sn24.9:3.17.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?

sn24.9:3.19.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn24.9:3.19.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a view arise?”

sn24.9:4.1.pli: “Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa imesu ca ṭhānesu kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti, dukkhepissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti …pe… dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāyapissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti—
sn24.9:4.1.eng: “When a noble disciple has given up doubt regarding these six grounds, and has given up doubt in suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,

sn24.9:4.2.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyano”ti.
sn24.9:4.2.eng: they’re called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn24.96:0.3.eng: The Self Is Neither Happy Nor Suffering

sn24.96:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.96:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.96:1.3.eng: ‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and is healthy after death’?”

sn24.96:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.96:2.1.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.96:2.1.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn24.96:2.2.eng: ‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and healthy after death.’

sn24.96:2.6.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.96:2.6.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:

sn24.96:2.7.eng: ‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and is healthy after death.’

sn24.96:3.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.96:3.4.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn24.96:3.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn24.96:3.6.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn24.96:3.7.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn24.96:3.14.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.96:3.14.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn24.96:3.16.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn24.96:3.16.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn24.96:3.17.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn24.96:4.1.pli: “Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn24.96:4.1.eng: “So you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn24.96:4.2.eng: You should truly see any kind of feeling …

sn24.96:4.5.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā, oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn24.96:4.5.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn24.96:5.1.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati, saññāyapi nibbindati, saṅkhāresupi nibbindati, viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati.
sn24.96:5.1.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn24.96:5.2.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati. Vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn24.96:5.2.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn24.96:5.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn24.96:5.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn24.96:6.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on views are complete.

sn25.1:1.1.comm: This chapter is named after the technical term “stepping into” (okkanti). Literally, it is to “step down” or “trample”, or in the context of rebirth to descend or “be conceived” in the womb. For the sense here, compare Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 4.4.5.11: the sacrificer is led to a still pool in flowing water, into which he “descends” seeking release from Varuṇa’s snare. Here the commentary glosses paviṭṭha (“entered”), which is supported by praveśa at Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 4.4.5.11. I use “step into” to disambiguate from “stream-entry” which is a different word (āpatti), even though the sense is similar.

sn25.1:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, the eye is impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.1:1.7.eng: and mind are impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.1:1.8.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, ime dhamme evaṃ saddahati adhimuccati—ayaṃ vuccati saddhānusārī, okkanto sammattaniyāmaṃ, sappurisabhūmiṃ okkanto, vītivatto puthujjanabhūmiṃ;
sn25.1:1.8.eng: Someone who has faith and confidence in these teachings is called a follower by faith. They’ve stepped into the sure path, they’ve stepped into the level of the true person, and they’ve passed beyond the level of the untrue person.
sn25.1:1.8.comm: This chapter offers some of the clearest details on the “follower by faith” (saddhānusārī) and “follower of teachings” (dhammānusārī), both of whom are “practicing to realize the fruit of stream-entry”. Elsewhere, they are distinguished by the degree of faculties (SN 48.12:1.5.). See too MN 22:46.2 and MN 34:10.2; also SN 55.24 and SN 55.25. | Sammatta (literally “rightness” or the “right way”) is defined as the noble eightfold path at SN 45.21:1.7. It is frequently used with niyāma (“fixedness, inevitability, surety”) to mean “the fixedness of the right way”. which I render more idiomatically as “sure path”.

sn25.1:1.9.pli: abhabbo taṃ kammaṃ kātuṃ, yaṃ kammaṃ katvā nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā pettivisayaṃ vā upapajjeyya;
sn25.1:1.9.eng: They can’t do any deed which would make them be reborn in hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.

sn25.1:1.10.pli: abhabbo ca tāva kālaṃ kātuṃ yāva na sotāpattiphalaṃ sacchikaroti.
sn25.1:1.10.eng: They can’t die without realizing the fruit of stream-entry.
sn25.1:1.10.comm: When the faith-follower realizes stream-entry, they are called “freed by faith” (saddhāvimutta, MN 70:19.1).

sn25.1:2.1.pli: Yassa kho, bhikkhave, ime dhammā evaṃ paññāya mattaso nijjhānaṃ khamanti, ayaṃ vuccati: ‘dhammānusārī, okkanto sammattaniyāmaṃ, sappurisabhūmiṃ okkanto, vītivatto puthujjanabhūmiṃ;
sn25.1:2.1.eng: Someone who accepts these teachings after deliberating them with a degree of wisdom is called a follower of teachings. They’ve stepped into the sure path, they’ve stepped into the level of the true person, and they’ve passed beyond the level of the untrue person.

sn25.1:2.2.pli: abhabbo taṃ kammaṃ kātuṃ, yaṃ kammaṃ katvā nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā pettivisayaṃ vā upapajjeyya;
sn25.1:2.2.eng: They can’t do any deed which would make them be reborn in hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.

sn25.1:2.3.pli: abhabbo ca tāva kālaṃ kātuṃ yāva na sotāpattiphalaṃ sacchikaroti’.
sn25.1:2.3.eng: They can’t die without realizing the fruit of stream-entry.
sn25.1:2.3.comm: When they realize stream-entry, they are called “attained to view” (diṭṭhippatta, MN 70:18.1).

sn25.1:2.4.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, ime dhamme evaṃ pajānāti evaṃ passati, ayaṃ vuccati: ‘sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyano’”ti.
sn25.1:2.4.eng: Someone who understands and sees these principles is called a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”
sn25.1:2.4.comm: This makes explicit a distinction that is consistently upheld throughout the Suttas. To “know and see” or to “truly understand” is, in this context, a distinct apperception of the four noble truths with intuitive wisdom that severs certain fetters forever. Those on the path to stream entry have not yet had such a realization, hence they must follow by faith, or by reflecting on the teachings. Though the conditions for realization are present, since they possess the five faculties and are on the path, they have not yet realized the fruit. Compare a mango tree that has been planted with good seeds in fertile soil, watered and sunned and protected from pests. At a certain point the conditions have been fulfilled for the fruit to appear, but it takes time for the conditions to mature.

sn25.10:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, form is impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.10:1.6.eng: and consciousness are impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.10:1.7.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, ime dhamme evaṃ saddahati adhimuccati, ayaṃ vuccati saddhānusārī, okkanto sammattaniyāmaṃ, sappurisabhūmiṃ okkanto, vītivatto puthujjanabhūmiṃ;
sn25.10:1.7.eng: Someone who has faith and confidence in these teachings is called a follower by faith. They’ve stepped into the sure path, they’ve stepped into the level of the true person, and they’ve passed beyond the level of the untrue person.

sn25.10:1.8.pli: abhabbo taṃ kammaṃ kātuṃ, yaṃ kammaṃ katvā nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā pettivisayaṃ vā upapajjeyya;
sn25.10:1.8.eng: They can’t do any deed which would make them be reborn in hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.

sn25.10:1.9.pli: abhabbo ca tāva kālaṃ kātuṃ yāva na sotāpattiphalaṃ sacchikaroti.
sn25.10:1.9.eng: They can’t die without realizing the fruit of stream-entry.

sn25.10:2.1.pli: Yassa kho, bhikkhave, ime dhammā evaṃ paññāya mattaso nijjhānaṃ khamanti, ayaṃ vuccati: ‘dhammānusārī, okkanto sammattaniyāmaṃ, sappurisabhūmiṃ okkanto, vītivatto puthujjanabhūmiṃ;
sn25.10:2.1.eng: Someone who accepts these teachings after deliberating them with a degree of wisdom is called a follower of teachings. They’ve stepped into the sure path, they’ve stepped into the level of the true person, and they’ve passed beyond the level of the untrue person.

sn25.10:2.2.pli: abhabbo taṃ kammaṃ kātuṃ, yaṃ kammaṃ katvā nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā pettivisayaṃ vā upapajjeyya;
sn25.10:2.2.eng: They can’t do any deed which would make them be reborn in hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.

sn25.10:2.3.pli: abhabbo ca tāva kālaṃ kātuṃ yāva na sotāpattiphalaṃ sacchikaroti’.
sn25.10:2.3.eng: They can’t die without realizing the fruit of stream-entry.

sn25.10:2.4.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, ime dhamme evaṃ pajānāti evaṃ passati, ayaṃ vuccati:
sn25.10:2.4.eng: Someone who understands and sees these principles is called

sn25.10:2.5.eng: a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn25.10:3.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on stepping into are complete.

sn25.2:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, sights are impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.2:1.7.eng: and ideas are impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.2:1.8.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, ime dhamme evaṃ saddahati adhimuccati, ayaṃ vuccati saddhānusārī, okkanto sammattaniyāmaṃ, sappurisabhūmiṃ okkanto, vītivatto puthujjanabhūmiṃ;
sn25.2:1.8.eng: Someone who has faith and confidence in these teachings is called a follower by faith. They’ve stepped into the sure path, they’ve stepped into the level of the true person, and they’ve passed beyond the level of the untrue person.

sn25.2:1.9.pli: abhabbo taṃ kammaṃ kātuṃ, yaṃ kammaṃ katvā nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā pettivisayaṃ vā upapajjeyya;
sn25.2:1.9.eng: They can’t do any deed which would make them be reborn in hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.

sn25.2:1.10.pli: abhabbo ca tāva kālaṃ kātuṃ yāva na sotāpattiphalaṃ sacchikaroti.
sn25.2:1.10.eng: They can’t die without realizing the fruit of stream-entry.

sn25.2:2.1.pli: Yassa kho, bhikkhave, ime dhammā evaṃ paññāya mattaso nijjhānaṃ khamanti, ayaṃ vuccati: ‘dhammānusārī, okkanto sammattaniyāmaṃ, sappurisabhūmiṃ okkanto, vītivatto puthujjanabhūmiṃ;
sn25.2:2.1.eng: Someone who accepts these teachings after deliberating them with a degree of wisdom is called a follower of teachings. They’ve stepped into the sure path, they’ve stepped into the level of the true person, and they’ve passed beyond the level of the untrue person.

sn25.2:2.2.pli: abhabbo taṃ kammaṃ kātuṃ, yaṃ kammaṃ katvā nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā pettivisayaṃ vā upapajjeyya;
sn25.2:2.2.eng: They can’t do any deed which would make them be reborn in hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.

sn25.2:2.3.pli: abhabbo ca tāva kālaṃ kātuṃ yāva na sotāpattiphalaṃ sacchikaroti’.
sn25.2:2.3.eng: They can’t die without realizing the fruit of stream-entry.

sn25.2:2.4.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, ime dhamme evaṃ pajānāti evaṃ passati, ayaṃ vuccati:
sn25.2:2.4.eng: Someone who understands and sees these principles is called

sn25.2:2.5.eng: a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn25.3:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, eye consciousness is impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.3:1.7.eng: and mind consciousness are impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.3:1.8.eng: Someone who has faith and confidence in these teachings is called a follower by faith. …”

sn25.4:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, eye contact is impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.4:1.7.eng: and mind contact are impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.4:1.8.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, ime dhamme evaṃ saddahati adhimuccati, ayaṃ vuccati ‘saddhānusārī …pe…
sn25.4:1.8.eng: Someone who has faith and confidence in these teachings is called a follower by faith. …”

sn25.5:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, feeling born of eye contact is impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.5:1.7.eng: and feeling born of mind contact are impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.5:1.8.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, ime dhamme evaṃ saddahati adhimuccati, ayaṃ vuccati ‘saddhānusārī …pe…
sn25.5:1.8.eng: Someone who has faith and confidence in these teachings is called a follower by faith. …”

sn25.6:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, perception of sights is impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.6:1.7.eng: and perception of ideas are impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.6:1.8.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, ime dhamme evaṃ saddahati adhimuccati, ayaṃ vuccati ‘saddhānusārī …pe…
sn25.6:1.8.eng: Someone who has faith and confidence in these teachings is called a follower by faith. …”

sn25.7:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, intention regarding sights is impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.7:1.7.eng: and intentions regarding ideas are impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.7:1.8.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, ime dhamme evaṃ saddahati adhimuccati, ayaṃ vuccati ‘saddhānusārī …pe…
sn25.7:1.8.eng: Someone who has faith and confidence in these teachings is called a follower by faith. …”

sn25.8:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, craving for sights is impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.8:1.7.eng: and craving for ideas are impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.8:1.8.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, ime dhamme evaṃ saddahati adhimuccati, ayaṃ vuccati ‘saddhānusārī …pe…
sn25.8:1.8.eng: Someone who has faith and confidence in these teachings is called a follower by faith. …”

sn25.9:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, the earth element is impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.9:1.7.eng: and the consciousness element are impermanent, decaying, and perishing.

sn25.9:1.8.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, ime dhamme evaṃ saddahati adhimuccati, ayaṃ vuccati ‘saddhānusārī …pe…
sn25.9:1.8.eng: Someone who has faith and confidence in these teachings is called a follower by faith. …”

sn26.1:1.1.comm: This chapter is built on the same template as the previous.

sn26.1:1.2.pli: “Yo kho, bhikkhave, cakkhussa uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo, dukkhasseso uppādo, rogānaṃ ṭhiti, jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo.
sn26.1:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, the arising, continuation, and manifestation and regeneration of the eye is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.

sn26.1:1.3.eng: The arising, continuation, and manifestation and regeneration of the ear,

sn26.1:1.7.pli: yo manassa uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo, dukkhasseso uppādo, rogānaṃ ṭhiti, jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo.
sn26.1:1.7.eng: and mind is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.

sn26.1:1.8.pli: Yo ca, bhikkhave, cakkhussa nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho, rogānaṃ vūpasamo, jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo.
sn26.1:1.8.eng: The cessation, settling, and disappearance of the eye is the cessation of suffering, the settling of diseases, and the disappearance of old age and death.

sn26.1:1.9.eng: The cessation, settling, and ending of the ear,

sn26.1:1.13.pli: yo manassa nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho, rogānaṃ vūpasamo, jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo”ti.
sn26.1:1.13.eng: and mind is the cessation of suffering, the settling of diseases, and the disappearance of old age and death.”

sn26.10:1.1.comm: This discourse is the same as SN 22.30.

sn26.10:1.2.pli: “Yo kho, bhikkhave, rūpassa uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo, dukkhasseso uppādo, rogānaṃ ṭhiti, jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo.
sn26.10:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, the arising, continuation, and manifestation and regeneration of form is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.

sn26.10:1.3.eng: The arising, continuation, and manifestation and regeneration of feeling,

sn26.10:1.6.pli: yo viññāṇassa uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo, dukkhasseso uppādo, rogānaṃ ṭhiti, jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo.
sn26.10:1.6.eng: and consciousness is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.

sn26.10:1.7.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, rūpassa nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho, rogānaṃ vūpasamo, jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo.
sn26.10:1.7.eng: The cessation, settling, and disappearance of form is the cessation of suffering, the settling of diseases, and the disappearance of old age and death.

sn26.10:1.8.eng: The cessation, settling, and ending of feeling,

sn26.10:1.11.pli: yo viññāṇassa nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho, rogānaṃ vūpasamo, jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo”ti.
sn26.10:1.11.eng: and consciousness is the cessation of suffering, the settling of diseases, and the disappearance of old age and death.”

sn26.10:2.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on arising are complete.

sn26.2:1.2.pli: “Yo kho, bhikkhave, rūpānaṃ uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo, dukkhasseso uppādo, rogānaṃ ṭhiti, jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo.
sn26.2:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, the arising, continuation, and manifestation and regeneration of sights is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.

sn26.2:1.3.eng: The arising, continuation, and manifestation and regeneration of sounds,

sn26.2:1.7.pli: yo dhammānaṃ uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo, dukkhasseso uppādo, rogānaṃ ṭhiti, jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo.
sn26.2:1.7.eng: and ideas is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.

sn26.2:1.8.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, rūpānaṃ nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho, rogānaṃ vūpasamo, jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo.
sn26.2:1.8.eng: The cessation, settling, and disappearance of sights,

sn26.2:1.13.pli: yo dhammānaṃ nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho, rogānaṃ vūpasamo, jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo”ti.
sn26.2:1.13.eng: and ideas is the cessation of suffering, the settling of diseases, and the disappearance of old age and death.”

sn26.3:1.5.eng: is the manifestation of old age and death.

sn26.3:1.6.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, cakkhuviññāṇassa nirodho …pe…

sn26.3:1.9.eng: is the disappearance of old age and death.”
